data.title: Family Life (1985)
data.meta_description: Every Saturday, to the great despair of his wife, Emmanuel finds his daughter Elise, fruit of a first union. A demanding and excessive father in his passions, he went to lay a loving trap for Elise.
data.text:
La Vie de Famille. Stunning. The early scenes set us up for a destructive, huis clos story of family enmity, but this section shares only a few things with what follows: a sunlit, edge-of-the-world holiday ambience, and the Sami Frey character’s difficult qualities. The young girl transforms the movie, of course: it turns into Pierrot le Fou, a story of the last romantic lovers, transposed to a father-daughter key - and of course Doillon does not hesitate to bring out the parallels to romantic love. The use of the video camera as a device that lets the characters speak their emotions with increasing directness, until fulfillment/exhaustion/sorrow is attained, is remarkable. The girl is a fantasy of complexity and articulateness, but…

Doillon at this most emotionally naked and pure, echoes of Pialat’s bruised nervous energy shot through with so many lyrical, digressive grace notes; the family unit envisioned as an unwieldy assemblage of competing wills and misperceptions and open wounds, but hopefully, subtending it all, something enough remaining beneath all the gaps. The opening swirl of volcanic emotions introduces Berto and a young Binoche as the seeming source of paterfamilias Sami Frey’s frayed nerves; but, fitting for a film that ends up adopting a freewheeling principle of drift, they turn out to be only the newest additions to his ever more complicated collection of fellow travelers. “Hysteria is becoming a habit of mine!” Eventually settling into a meandering road trip through…

We have thousands of portraits about broken families but I've come to realize that no one deals these subjects with such authenticity as the French. I'm going to be as honest as I can be when I say that I have no clue how Doillon does that. The chemistry between Sami Frey and young Mara Goyet is the kind of purely cinematic chemistry that we have seen with the greatest, the likes of Bogie and Bacall and Doillon indeed structures their relationship on the Hawksian approach of badinage with unsaid emotions behind every word. That is why the finale is so heartbreaking; it sums up the whole film tragically but at the same time bursts out the feelings that have…
